Infectious diseases (such as viral or bacterial infections)
Schizophrenia (considering psychosis as a primary symptom)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Interstitial Lung Disease
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia + Immune Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers
diagnoses.description: A group of illnesses caused by four families of viruses including Ebola and Dengue, characterized by fever and bleeding disorders that can lead to shock and death.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the heart's inner lining, usually involving the heart valves.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by a tick, characterized by fever, headache, and a rash.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A type of juvenile idiopathic arthritis that can cause inflammation in one or more joints and is characterized by daily fevers and a rash.

diagnoses.name: Leptospirosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial disease that affects humans and animals, caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.description: The second stage of syphilis, featuring skin rash, mucous membrane lesions, and flu-like symptoms.

diagnoses: Lupus Nephritis specifically for nephritis manifestation

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Allergic reactions
diagnoses.description: An exaggerated response of the immune system to a substance, potentially aligning with symptoms like hyperactivity (due to discomfort or distress) and cough, and rare reactions such as Kounis syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Respiratory tract infections
diagnoses.description: Infections of the parts of the body involved in breathing, such as the larynx, which could explain laryngitis and cough.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus, leading to cough and potentially triggering or worsening hyperactivity due to difficulty breathing.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining, possibly leading to laryngitis and cough.

diagnoses.name: Periodontitis
diagnoses.description: A severe gum infection that can lead to tooth loss and other serious health complications, directly explaining periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety disorders
diagnoses.description: Mental health disorders characterized by significant amounts of anxiety or fear, potentially leading to symptoms like hyperactivity.

diagnoses.name: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make it difficult to breathe, explaining cough and potentially exacerbating symptoms of laryngitis due to the chronic inflammation and strain on the respiratory system.

diagnoses.name: Heart disease
diagnoses.description: Covers a range of heart conditions, with some forms potentially connected to Kounis syndrome, a rare allergic reaction affecting the coronary arteries.

diagnoses.name: Vocal cord dysfunction
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes incorrect closing or opening of the vocal cords, leading to symptoms like laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by a pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development, providing a clear link to hyperactivity symptoms.

diagnoses: Iron deficiency anemia (related to ulcers causing chronic blood loss, potentially exacerbating thrombocytosis in a reactive process)
Type 2 diabetes mellitus (related to glycemic lability)
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) (considering attention deficit as a symptom)
Endometrial cancer (considering a potential link or confusion with symptoms of endometriosis; advanced cases can present with complex symptoms including thrombocytosis)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Diabetes Mellitus can cause sensory neuropathies due to chronic hyperglycemia leading to damage to the peripheral nerves. Diabetes may also lead to conditions contributing to diarrhea and potentially influence skin and nail health, possibly explaining onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Vasculitis involves inflammation of the blood vessels, which can lead to arteriovenous malformations if the inflammation and damage are severe enough. It might indirectly contribute to neuropathies and skin issues.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Behçet's disease is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. It can lead to symptoms like skin and mucosal membrane lesions, which could explain vaginitis and possibly onychodystrophy. Gastrointestinal symptoms, including diarrhea, are also a part of its manifestation, as well as possibly contributing to vascular issues.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting the exocrine glands but can also cause peripheral neuropathy. Gastrointestinal symptoms and vaginal dryness leading to vaginitis could be related. However, direct associations with arteriovenous malformations and onychodystrophy are less clear.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide array of symptoms, including neuropathies due to either the disease itself or secondary vasculitis, skin, and nail changes including onychodystrophy, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder affecting the intestine in reaction to gluten, can cause diarrhea. It can also lead to dermatitis herpetiformis, which might be confused with or contribute to skin and nail symptoms. Peripheral neuropathy is a recognized neurological manifestation of celiac disease.

diagnoses.name: Crohn’s Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Inflammatory bowel disease like Crohn’s can primarily manifest with gastrointestinal symptoms including diarrhea. It is associated with extraintestinal manifestations such as skin and nail problems, and while less common, it can contribute to neuropathic complications.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV infection, particularly in the advanced stage known as AIDS, can cause a wide array of symptoms due to its immune suppression capabilities, including sensory neuropathies, diarrhea, and vaginitis due to opportunistic infections. HIV-associated vasculopathy can mimic arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: Late-stage syphilis can manifest with neurological complications (neuropathies), and it also has the capability to cause skin lesions. Gastrointestinal involvement is less commonly reported but possible. It's noted for its capacity to infect and cause damage across multiple organ systems.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus
diagnoses.reasoning: Lichen Planus is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting skin and mucous membranes, potentially leading to onychodystrophy and vaginitis due to mucosal involvement. While not typically associated with arteriovenous malformations, its widespread inflammatory nature could have secondary effects on the vasculature and peripheral nerve function.

diagnoses: Vitamin B12 deficiency or Zinc deficiency (related to dysgeusia)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by two most common symptoms - dry eyes and a dry mouth. It often accompanies other immune system disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. In Sjögren's syndrome, the mucous membranes and moisture-secreting glands of your eyes and mouth are usually affected first — resulting in decreased tears and saliva.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by cryoglobulins in the blood. Cryoglobulins are proteins, which are normally dissolved in the blood, that become solid or gel-like in cold temperatures. Cryoglobulinemia can cause a variety of symptoms including skin rashes, joint pain, and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare but serious immune disorder characterized by severe swelling, particularly of the face, airways, and gastrointestinal tract. The swelling is due to a genetic fault that affects the blood protein called C1 inhibitor. Symptoms can be triggered by stress, minor trauma, or unknown factors.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by an influenza virus. Symptoms can be mild to severe and commonly include high fever, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, muscle or body aches, headaches, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the immune system reacts abnormally to a foreign substance. Symptoms can range from mild, such as sneezing and coughing, to more severe symptoms like difficulty breathing and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In rheumatoid arthritis, the body's immune system attacks its own tissue, including the joints. In severe cases, it attacks internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Periodontitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the gums that can lead to tooth loss if untreated. Symptoms include swollen gums, bright red or purplish gums, gums that feel tender when touched, gums that pull away from your teeth (recede), making your teeth look longer than normal, and new spaces developing between your teeth.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. Without treatment, HIV can lead to AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome). Symptoms can include rapid weight loss, recurring fever or profuse night sweats, extreme and unexplained tiredness, and more.

diagnoses.name: Hypothermia
diagnoses.description: A medical emergency that occurs when your body loses heat faster than it can produce heat, causing a dangerously low body temperature. When your body temperature drops, your heart, nervous system, and other organs can't work normally.

diagnoses: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA, Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
Chronic Immunodeficiency Disorders (e.g., Common Variable Immunodeficiency)
Gastrointestinal Disorders (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Celiac Disease)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with preserved pulmonary function
Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF)
Secondary vulvodynia due to dermatological conditions
Psychological conditions affecting perception of pain and smell

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to symptoms such as laryngeal edema, pruritus, abdominal cramps, and potentially syncope due to a sudden drop in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, causing symptoms like pruritus, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and possibly laryngeal edema.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other parts of the body, leading to symptoms such as pruritus, syncope, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and potentially laryngeal edema.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that results in recurrent episodes of severe swelling (edema), which may include laryngeal edema, abdominal cramps, and in some cases, diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Medication-Induced Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to medication that can cause severe symptoms including syncope, laryngeal edema, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the venom from insect stings, which can lead to anaphylaxis, manifesting as syncope, laryngeal edema, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Peanut and Tree Nut Allergy
diagnoses.description: A common food allergy that can trigger severe allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, with symptoms such as pruritus, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, syncope, and laryngeal edema.

diagnoses.name: Latex Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to natural rubber latex, which can cause various symptoms including pruritus, laryngeal edema, abdominal cramps, and potential syncope in more severe reactions.

diagnoses.name: Shellfish Allergy
diagnoses.description: An adverse immune response to proteins in shellfish, leading to symptoms that can include pruritus, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, laryngeal edema, and possibly syncope in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic skin condition caused by contact with a substance or allergen, leading to pruritus and potentially other symptoms like abdominal cramps in reaction to ingested allergens, though less common for symptoms like syncope or laryngeal edema.

diagnoses: Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms)
Asthma (reactive airway disease causing wheezing and hypoxia)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells start to die within minutes.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is usually severe and comes with visual disturbances (aura) such as flashes of light, blind spots, or other vision changes; sensory changes or speech difficulties might also occur.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms depend on the size, location, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA doesn’t cause permanent damage. They are caused by a temporary decrease in blood supply to part of your brain.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess is a collection of pus that has built up within the tissue of the body. When it occurs in the brain, it can cause a range of neurological symptoms, including headache, weakness, confusion, seizures, and problems with vision like scotomas.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.
A type of headache accompanied by visual disturbances (scotoma), sensitivity to sound (phonophobia), difficulty speaking (aphasia), and sensory disturbances (numbness).
Often called a mini-stroke, it can cause temporary symptoms similar to a stroke, including headache, aphasia, and numbness.
A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like aphasia, numbness, and headache.
A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include numbness, weakness, and problems with vision and speech.
Abnormal cells in the brain can cause symptoms like headache, numbness, speech difficulties, and vision problems.
A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, and stiff neck.
A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, neurologic deficits, and seizures.
An inflammation of the brain. Can cause flu-like symptoms, including a severe headache, aphasia, phonophobia, numbness, and weakness.
Low blood sugar, a condition that can provoke migraines or headache, neurological symptoms like numbness, and cognitive impairments including aphasia.

diagnoses: Brain Tumors (especially in the posterior fossa or brainstem)
Vasculitis (specifically Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Lupus nephritis (if considering proteinuria specifically as a symptom)
